qas.question: How many rules were proposed in the 1881 publication of the New Testament in Greek?

answers.text: The reading is less likely to be original that shows a disposition to smooth away difficulties.

qas.question: Does ease of reading correlate to accuracy in relation to the original text?

answers.text: "The reading is to be preferred that most fitly explains the existence of the others."

qas.question: What is more important for a textual critic: quality or quantity?

answers.text: Readings are approved or rejected by reason of the quality, and not the number, of their supporting witnesses

qas.question: What is the criteria needed to include or dismiss a reading when critiquing texts?

answers.text: The reading is to be preferred that most fitly explains the existence of the others.

qas.question: When did Westcott and Hort meet?
When did Westcott and Hort go into business together?
When did they propose Bengel's rule?
The number of supporting witnesses explains why readings are what?

plausible_answers.text: most fitly explains the existence of the others.

context: Brooke Foss Westcott (1825–<b5_0>1901<b5_0/>) and Fenton J. A. Hort (1828–<b7_0>1892<b7_0/>) published an edition of the New Testament in Greek in <b6_0>1881<b6_0/>. <a0_0>They proposed nine critical rules<a0_0/>, including a version of Bengel's rule, "<a1_0>The reading is less likely to be original that shows a disposition to smooth away difficulties.<a1_0/>" They also argued that "<a3_0>Readings are <b8_0>approved or rejected<b8_0/> by reason of the quality, and not the number, of their supporting witnesses<a3_0/>", and that <a2_0>"<a4_0>The reading is to be preferred that <b9_0>most fitly explains the existence of the others.<b9_0/><a4_0/>"
